content.webTitle: Review: Eugénie Grandet by Honoré de Balzac

fields.headline: Eugénie Grandet
fields.bodyText: English literature has some memorable stony-hearted misers but they pale beside Balzac's provincial Midas, Monsieur Grandet, father of the long-suffering Eugénie. Grandet's wealth is legendary and, inevitably, when Charles, his elegant, foppish nephew from Paris, turns up, Eugénie, accustomed to her father's spartan frugality, is hopelessly smitten. But marriage is out of the question. Charles's father is bankrupt, so the young dandy must go to the West Indies to seek his fortune (Grandet offers to pay his fare as far as Nantes), and poor trusting Eugénie vows to wait for him. A sombre cautionary tale read by Peter Joyce with apt darkness and dignity.
